name: Sun
additional_info: The Sun, also known as the 'ruler' of the Solar System, accounts for over 99% of its total mass. Its continuous solar winds significantly affect asteroids and the magnetospheres of planets. The Sun is roughly at mid-life and will continue to burn for over 5 billion years before evolving into a red giant.
structure: About three-quarters of the Sun’s mass is hydrogen, with helium making up most of the remainder. A small fraction (around 1.69%) consists of heavier elements such as carbon, neon, iron, and oxygen. The Sun is divided into layers: the core, the radiative zone, the convective zone, and the photosphere (the visible 'surface').
distance: The average distance from Earth to the Sun is about 149.6 million km (1 astronomical unit). Sunlight takes around 8 minutes and 19 seconds to reach Earth, providing essential energy for life.
in_milky_way: The Sun is located on the inner edge of the Orion Arm of the Milky Way, about 26,000 light-years from the galactic center. Although not exceptionally large compared to many stars, it still outshines about 85% of the stars in our galaxy.

name: Earth
additional_info: Earth is the only known planet in the Solar System that supports life. It also has a strong magnetosphere, protecting its biosphere from harmful solar radiation and cosmic rays.
structure: Earth’s atmosphere is primarily composed of nitrogen (around 78%) and oxygen (about 21%), with small amounts of argon, carbon dioxide, and other gases. Around 71% of Earth's surface is covered by water, most of which is salty ocean water. Tectonic plate movements shape continents, forming mountains and causing earthquakes.
distance: The average distance between Earth and the Sun is 149.6 million km, known as 1 astronomical unit (AU). Earth orbits the Sun at a speed of about 30 km/s.
in_milky_way: Our planet resides in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way, roughly 26,000 light-years from the galactic center. It completes one orbit around the galaxy (a 'cosmic year') in about 225–250 million years.

name: Moon
additional_info: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite and the fifth largest satellite in the Solar System. Its presence stabilizes Earth’s axial tilt and strongly influences ocean tides.
structure: The Moon’s surface is covered with countless impact craters from meteorites. The darker plains known as 'maria' are ancient lava flows that have cooled into relatively smooth basaltic areas.
distance: The average distance between Earth and the Moon is about 384,400 km. Because the Moon’s rotation period matches its orbital period, the same side always faces Earth.
in_milky_way: Together with Earth, the Moon lies in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way. Its gravitational interaction helps maintain a stable climate for life on Earth.

name: Mercury
description: The closest planet to the Sun
additional_info: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun. It experiences extreme temperature fluctuations due to its lack of a dense atmosphere.
structure: Mercury’s surface is heavily cratered, with large basins spanning hundreds of kilometers. Its metallic core is proportionally bigger than that of any other planet, giving Mercury the second-highest density after Earth.
distance: The average distance from Mercury to the Sun is about 57.9 million km. With an 88-day orbital period, Mercury completes its revolution around the Sun faster than any other planet.
in_milky_way: Mercury is in the Solar System’s Orion Arm within the Milky Way, at roughly one-third Earth’s distance from the Sun.

name: Saturn
additional_info: Saturn stands out with its extensive ring system composed mostly of ice and small rocky particles. It has the lowest density among the planets in the Solar System, so low it would float if placed in a large enough body of water.
structure: Saturn’s rings consist of countless ice and rock fragments, ranging from tiny grains to meter-sized chunks. Beneath its massive atmosphere is a layer of metallic hydrogen that generates Saturn’s magnetic field.
distance: The average distance between Saturn and the Sun is about 1.4 billion km. Sunlight takes over an hour to travel from the Sun to Saturn.
in_milky_way: Saturn orbits within the Orion Arm of the Milky Way, alongside the Sun. One galactic revolution of the Solar System takes about 225–250 million years.

name: Mars
additional_info: Mars has a dusty, red surface due to iron oxide. Once featuring liquid water, scientists are investigating past or present life. Olympus Mons, the largest volcano in the Solar System, stands at about 21.9 km high.
structure: Mars’s thin atmosphere is dominated by carbon dioxide, with traces of argon and nitrogen. The planet also hosts Valles Marineris, a colossal canyon system extending over 4,000 km.
distance: The average distance between Mars and the Sun is about 227.9 million km. During opposition, Mars can come as close as around 55 million km to Earth.
in_milky_way: Mars resides in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way, orbiting the Sun. It has been a prime target for exploration due to its potential for past habitability and future human missions.

name: Jupiter
additional_info: Jupiter is more massive than all other planets combined. Its Great Red Spot is a giant storm that has raged for at least three centuries, making it a prominent feature for astronomers.
structure: Primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, Jupiter’s atmosphere also contains traces of methane, ammonia, and water. Rapid rotation forms distinct bands around the planet, while a deep layer of metallic hydrogen generates its intense magnetic field.
distance: Orbiting at an average distance of 778.5 million km, Jupiter can be as close as about 588 million km to Earth during certain alignments, making it easily visible even with small telescopes.
in_milky_way: Jupiter moves together with the Sun in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way. Its enormous gravity captures many comets and asteroids, offering some protection to the inner Solar System.

name: Uranus
additional_info: Uranus has an axial tilt of about 98°, causing its poles to almost directly face the Sun for extended periods and resulting in extremely unusual seasonal changes. It was the first planet discovered by telescope, in 1781.
structure: Its atmosphere consists mainly of hydrogen and helium, with methane providing the planet’s pale blue color. Beneath lies a vast icy mantle of water, ammonia, and methane, surrounding a small rocky core.
distance: Uranus is about 2.9 billion km from the Sun on average. Sunlight takes more than 2.5 hours to travel that far.
in_milky_way: Uranus is part of the Solar System within the Orion Arm of the Milky Way, following the galactic orbit along with the Sun. Classified as an 'ice giant,' it endures extremely cold temperatures at such a great distance.

name: Neptune
additional_info: Neptune has the strongest winds in the Solar System, reaching up to 2,100 km/h. Discovered in 1846 through mathematical predictions, it symbolizes human scientific accomplishment.
structure: Its atmosphere is primarily hydrogen, helium, and methane, giving Neptune a striking deep blue color. A high-pressure 'mantle' of water, ammonia, and methane is thought to produce 'diamond rain' at extreme depths.
distance: Neptune’s average distance from the Sun is about 4.5 billion km. One Neptunian year lasts roughly 164.8 Earth years.
in_milky_way: Neptune is the outermost planet in the Solar System (excluding dwarf planets), also located in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way. It orbits the galactic center with the Sun over hundreds of millions of years.

name: Venus
additional_info: Venus is the hottest planet in the Solar System, dominated by a runaway greenhouse effect. Its atmospheric pressure is over 90 times that of Earth, and it’s sometimes called Earth’s 'sister planet' due to their similar size.
structure: Venus’s atmosphere is composed mainly of carbon dioxide (about 96.5%) and nitrogen (3.5%), with thick clouds of sulfuric acid. The dense cloud cover conceals a surface featuring thousands of volcanoes and rugged terrain.
distance: Venus orbits the Sun at an average distance of about 108 million km. Interestingly, it rotates in the opposite direction of most other planets, causing the Sun to rise in the west and set in the east.
in_milky_way: Venus also resides in the Orion Arm of the Milky Way. Sometimes it comes very close to Earth, making it shine brilliantly in the night sky as the 'morning star' or 'evening star.'
